Tutorial: Data from NDA

Date: February 15, 2024 12:02 PM

Database: National Data Archive at the United States National Institute of Health

Helpdesk Contact: ndahelp@mail.nih.gov

âœï¸ Tutorial Contents:

Youtube Tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=53P6hEy-zaM

1) Have an eRA Profile

  1. Make sure you have an eRA account. If you donâ€™t have one, email the RBHS signing official, Gregory Werhner (gw266@research.rutgers.edu) to have one created for you
  2. Ask your PI what institution theyâ€™re assigned to as a PI in NDA. Then put in your employment, making sure to select the same institution as they have.
    1. For example, there are 2 versions of RBHS. â€œRutgers Biomedical and Health Sciencesâ€, and â€œRutgers Biomedical/Health Sciences - RBHSâ€. Thereâ€™s also â€œRutgers, the State University of NJâ€ and others. Make sure to select the one that matches your PI
  3. Change your contact email to your Rutgers email

1) Get Access to NDA

  1. Create an NDA account (nda tutorial): Go to the NDA website:Â https://nda.nih.gov/. To create an account, click the â€œlog inâ€ button in the top right which will prompt a few â€œcreate accountâ€ options. Make sure to link to your eRA or login.gov which is listed with your institutional email
  2. After/if you already have an account, go to â€œProfileâ€ and make sure your institutional affiliation is the same as listed on your eRA account / your PIâ€™s institutional affiliation.
    1. If itâ€™s not, email the helpdesk ndahelp@mail.nih.gov and ask it to be changed

1.1) Be added to an existing DUC for the NDA dataset(s) you wish to use

  1. Have the PI/primary requestor add your name to the existing DUC from the NDA website
  2. Have the PI download the Data Access Request (DAR)
  3. Follow steps 3-5 from 1B

1.2) Request Access under a new DUC to the NDA dataset(s) you wish to use

If your PI doesnâ€™t already have a Data Use Agreement (DUA) for the dataset you wish to use, you must request permissions.

  1. First, make sure your PIâ€™s â€˜Institutional affiliationâ€™ is the same as yours
  2. Have your PI go to Profile > Data Permissions > scroll down to the collectionâ€¦ > Request Access (PI must start a request to the data collection that holds the dataset youâ€™re interested in)
  3. Fill project specific fieldsâ€” example responses :
    1. Name of Project: â€œPsychiatric connectomesâ€
      1. Not important, doesnâ€™t have to match anywhere else
    2. Research purpose: â€œOur research is looking at the relationship between biological biomarkers, such as MRI and fMRI, and behavioral markers such as clinical phenotypes and task-behavior. â€œ

  4. Fill in the other two fieldsâ€” USE THIS LANGUAGE for these questions:

    Data access plan: â€œThe data will be stored on a secure server, in a password protected partition on the Rutgers University Amarel computing cluster. The folder will only be accessible by those listed in this DUA.â€

    Plan for deletion: â€œAll data that has been downloaded from this dataset will be deleted from all our local or cloud-based machines when research is completed, or this DUC is expired, whichever comes first.â€œ

  5. Then add everyone who will access the data
    1. If the person has an NDA account: but you donâ€™t see them on the list of â€œKnown affiliated userâ€ you have to ask them to follow steps 1.a.-1.c.
      1. Make sure to select the email associated with your collaboratorâ€™s NDA account. Donâ€™t press â€˜add new userâ€™ unless your collaborator doesnâ€™t have an NDA account already
  6. For â€œSigning Officialâ€, select Chrissa Pappannoiu **cp847@ored.rutgers.edu
  7. Download the DUC file (auto-created)
    1. E-sign it as the Lead Recipient

  8. Email the signed file to Gregory Werhner cp847@ored.rutgers.edu
    1. Message: â€œHi Chrissa, Iâ€™m a researcher in the Holmes Lab and weâ€™re applying for access to the NDA dataset [Enter dataset name] for the purposes of scientific investigation. The data will be stored on a secure server, in a password protected file on the Rutgers University Amarel computing cluster. The folder will only be accessible by those listed in this DUA. All raw data will be deleted after the conclusion of the project.â€

  9. Once you receive it back signed, upload the DUC (signed by both of you) to the â€œUpload Supporting Documentationâ€ under â€œactive requestsâ€

  10. Wait to get granted access

1C) Get added to your PIâ€™s existing collection/dataset

For PI/Administrators: How to Add Users to Your NDA Collection

  1. Have the user create an NDA account.

  2. Click on the Permissions tab on your NDA Collection.

  3. Enter either the NDA username or email address of the person you wish to add.

  4. Click on search.

  5. Click on Add User.

  6. Apply the desired permission level.

  7. Click Save on the bottom left of the screen.

ğŸŒŸ For more information, please see: PDF Tutorial: [https://rutgers.box.com/s/fh8iv3luan3xonevzyijf185shpzavvm](https://rutgers.box.com/s/fh8iv3luan3xonevzyijf185shpzavvm) Youtube Tutorial: [NDA Data Access Webinar](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=53P6hEy-zaM&embeds_referring_euri=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.notion.so%2F&source_ve_path=MjM4NTE&feature=emb_title)

2) Creating Python environment for Data Downloads

  1. Create Conda environment
#first create a conda environemnt for the NDA downloader tool. Might not be needed, but was considered good practise the milgram cluster 
conda create --name NDA_download  python=3.11
conda activate NDA_download

#Do this every time
#install nda-tools package:
pip install nda-tools

#see if it worked 
conda list

3) Downloading Data from NDA to Compute Cluster

  1. go to nda.nih.gov
  2. sign in
  3. search the dataset you want

    1. Get Data > Text Search > â€œdataset nameâ€

  4. select it from the search results and press â€œAdd to Workspaceâ€

  5. see that the number of subjects in the â€œFilter Cartâ€ in the upper right hand corner is the appropriate amount. If so, press â€˜Create Data Package/Add Data to Studyâ€™

  6. Press â€œGo to Data Packaging Pageâ€ (if it doesnâ€™t automatically) and select from the checkboxes all the data you want
    1. on the left â€œCollections By Permission Groupâ€ is the collections/datasets and all their iterations
    2. on the right â€œData Structure by Categoryâ€ is the types of data within it
      1. deselect if you donâ€™t want it

  7. Press â€œCreate Data Packageâ€ button
    1. Clear name so you can reference back
    2. Make SURE to check the box for â€œInclude associated data filesâ€
    3. press â€œCreate Data Packageâ€

  8. You should get a popup like this. Go to dashboard via link or go to your User Profile (https://nda.nih.gov/user/dashboard/profile.html) and click on Data Packages

  9. Your packages should look like this, including the one you just made. The just-made one will say Status: â€œCreating Packageâ€ for a couple minutes, but then will populate with Status: â€œReady to Downloadâ€ and the size

  10. When it says â€œready to downloadâ€ and the size seems right, copy the Package ID Number in the first column for the package you want to download

  11. Open text editor (BBEdit, Textedit, VSCode, etc.) and paste this code

    (downloadcmd is a command from the package nda-tools)

        
downloadcmd -dp 1225580 -d /projects/f_ah1491_1/Open_Data/NAPLS3 -wt 5
  • -wt = the number of files you download in parallel. You should use max 10.
  • change 1225580 to YOUR PACKAGE ID
  • change /projects/f_ah1491_1 to the FOLDER YOU WANT TO DOWNLOAD TO
    1. Save this file as a NAME.sh file, and have NAME be relevant to the package youâ€™re downloading
    2. Go to terminal, input chmod u+rwx [NAME.sh](http://NAME.sh) to make sure you have execute permissions
    3. Code Template:

    Just out file

      /path/to/my_script.sh 1>/path/to/my_script.out &

    Out file and error file

      /path/to/my_script.sh 1>/path/to/my_script.out 2>/path/to/my_script.err &

    This will run your script in the background (&) and save out the terminal outputs into a file with the same name but a different extension (.out) and the error files into that name but (.err)

  1. It should prompt you here for your username and password from NDA. Make sure these are the credentials that link to the account where you created the data package!
  2. Once the job starts running, you can check itâ€™s running and its progress by entering sacct
    1. Your job should be listed in a table like this

    2. your job is the one that says â€˜mainâ€™ at the top, in this example itâ€™s â€˜shell_dca+â€™ (which is the beginning of the shellfile.sh name). this is the one that should be â€˜RUNNINGâ€™ and â€˜COMPLETEDâ€™. if this one fails, the â€˜batchâ€™ or â€˜externâ€™ files may say â€˜COMPLETEDâ€™, but your job has still failed

If it says â€œFAILEDâ€:

  1. Check the error file by displaying it, itâ€™s called slurm.most.recent.err if you kept it as I have above, or itâ€™s called however you defined in the shellfile.sh file

    vi slurm.most.recent.err

    (:q to quit the vi viewer)

    or

    cat slurm.most.recent.err

Now that you see the problem, you can try to fix it!

  • if it says â€˜permission deniedâ€™, try making sure both .sh files are fully rwx accessible to you, and the folders that hold those files are as well
  • if it says â€˜file cannot be foundâ€™, check all the filepaths in your files for errors, and make sure they line up exactly to where the files are
  • if it is a new error or you canâ€™t figure it out, ask other members of your lab or Rutgersâ€™ Office of Advanced Research Computing (help@oarc.rutgers.edu)

4) More Information:
